page.title: PostâWorld War II air-to-air combat losses

revisions.rev:
[[File:North Vietnamese fighter.jpg|thumb|alt=Blurry Gun camera photo shows a North Vietnamese MiG-17-fighter.|Gun camera photo shows a North Vietnamese [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-17|MiG-17-fighter]] during the [[Vietnam War]]]] [[Air-to-air combat]] is the engagement of flying machines in [[warfare]]. The Korean War saw the greatest amount of air to air combat since World War II. During the war the Americans claimed to have shot down around 700 communist [[Mikoyan|MiG]] fighters{{#tag:ref|During the [[Korean War]] the Communist Airforces used experienced [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] pilots to fly against UN forces.{{harvnb|Brune|1996|p=215}}|group="A"}}{{harvnb|Dorr|Thompson|2003| p=186}} After the war the USAF reviewed their figures in an investigation code-named Sabre Measure Charlie and downgraded the kill ratio of the [[F-86 Sabre]] against the [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-15|MiG]] 15 by half from 14:1 to 7:1. One of the factors in the inflated US numbers was that because most dogfights took place over enemy controlled area the only way to confirm kills was the gun camera. American pilots were credited with a kill if the gun camera showed their guns striking the plane even if no one actually saw the plane go down.{{harvnb|Zhang|2004|p=153}} This contrasted with Soviet methodology that required other pilots' testimony, ground evidence, gun camera footage and support from the Chinese and Korean ground forces. The [[Vietnam War]] saw a move away from cannon fire to air-to-air missiles.{{harvnb|Boyne|2002|p= 2}} Although American forces maintained air supremacy throughout the war there were still occasional dogfights and several American [[flying ace|aces]]. The North Vietnamese side claimed the [[Vietnam People's Air Force]] had [[List of Vietnam War flying aces|17 aces]] throughout the war, including the possibly mythological [[Nguyen Toon|Colonel Toon]] who allegedly shot down 13 planes. The Israeli Air Force has the most experience with air-to-air combat in recent decades. Since the 1948 Israeli War, the IAF have only lost 18 planes in dogfights while Arab forces have lost 817 in air-to-air combat.{{harvnb|Cordesman|2006|p=119}} During the 1947 conflict over [[Jammu and Kashmir (princely state)|Jammu and Kashmir]], the Royal Indian AF did not engage Pakistan Air Force in air-to-air combat; however, it did provide effective transport and close air support to the Indian troops.{{Harvnb|Barua|2005|p=192|Ref=Barua}} The [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1965]] was the first time the InAF actively engaged an enemy air force.{{Harvnb|Pradhan|Chavan|2007|p=xiv|Ref=ybChavan}} By the time the conflict had ended, Pakistan claimed to have shot down 113 IAF aircraft while the Indians claimed that 73 PAF aircraft were downed.{{Harvnb|Barua|2005|p=193|Ref=Barua}} More than 60% of InAF's air combat losses took place during the disastrous battles over Kalaikunda and Pathankot; where most of the losses were on the ground.{{Harvnb|Khan|2004|p=185|Ref=Khan}} The [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1971]] started with a preemptive strike by Pakistani Air Force; the Indian air force retaliated the next day and quickly achieved air superiority.http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/war/indo-pak_1971.htm IAF flew 4000 sorties during the war resulting in destruction of Sqn No. 14 of PAF and playing an significant role in [[Bangladesh_Liberation_War|liberation of Bangladesh]]. [[No._22_Squadron,_Indian_Air_Force|Squadron 22]] earned the nickname '''Sabre Slayers''' during the war. During [[Iran-Iraq War]] 1980-88, there were nearly 1000 air-to-air engagements between Iran and Iraq.http://www.airspacemag.com/military-aviation/persiancats.html [[Falkland War]] of 1982 witnessed air combat between Argentine Air Force and British Air Services. Falkland's runway were short and thus unable to support fighter jets forcing AAF to launch fighters from mainland which had an adverse effect on their loiter time. AAF lost 65 fixed wing aircraft and 35 helicopters while BAS lost 10 fighters and 24 helicopters.http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Falklands_War#Escalation_of_the_air_war During the [[Gulf War|Persian Gulf War]] 1990-91, of Iraq's 750 fixed wing aircraft, 109 fled to Iran, 151 were hit on the ground and 33 were shot down, compared to the single confirmed loss of one coalition [[F/A-18 Hornet|F/A 18]]. ==Aircraft lost to air to air combat== {| class="wikitable sortable" width="100%" |- ! Conflict ! Air Force ! [[Iraqi no-fly zones|Iraqi no-fly zones enforcement]]}} |align=left| {{flagicon|US}} [[United States armed forces|US Aircraft]] | 3 {{#tag:ref|The [[1994 Black Hawk shootdown incident]], sometimes referred to as the '''Black Hawk Incident''', was a [[friendly fire]] incident over northern [[Iraq]] that occurred on April 14, 1994 during [[Operation Provide Comfort]] (OPC). The pilots of two [[United States Air Force]] (USAF) [[F-15 Eagle|F-15]] [[fighter aircraft]], operating under the control of a USAF [[airborne warning and control system]] (AWACS) aircraft, misidentified two [[United States Army]] [[UH-60 Black Hawk]] [[helicopters]] as Iraqi [[Mil Mi-24]] "Hind" helicopters. The F-15 pilots fired on and destroyed both helicopters, killing all 26 military service members and civilians from the United States (U.S.), United Kingdom, France, Turkey, and the [[Kurdish people|Kurdish community]]. The third loss was a UAV Predator shot down by a Mig-25 in December 2002.|group="A"}} |One [[General Atomics MQ-1 Predator|Predator]] was shot by a Mig-25 on December 27, 2002. Knights, Michael (2005).''Cradle of conflict: Iraq and the birth of modern U.S. military power''. Naval Institute Press, p. 242.
